body: I'm away from my computer so can't give a full response right now. For one, don't run `python -m stata_kernel.install` again after modifying the configuration file. Any time you run that it resets the configuration to defaults.
I think the second error means that the Stata path is off. If you paste it into the terminal it should start the Stata console

Thank you for the quick response. I updated the config file and it still having the same issue, which is that it launches Stata, but then Stata crashes after about 10-15 seconds and gets into a loop. I'll try reinstalling Stata, reinstalling the kernel from the beginning and then updating the .conf file directly and see if that helps.

Thanks again. Greg

I took the following steps.
1. Uninstall stata_kernel
2. Uninstall Stata
3. Reinstall Stata IC from Stata website and run updates (none necessary). Close open Stata instance.
4. Install stata_kernel and run `python -m stata_kernel.install`
5. Modify `.stata_kernel.conf` line 5 to read `stata_path = /Applications/Stata/StataIC.app/Contents/MacOS/StataIC
`
6. Confirm StataIC path by running `/Applications/Stata/StataIC.app/Contents/MacOS/StataIC` directly from the terminal - confirmed that Stata launches.
7.  Launch Jupyter Notebook and create new notebook using Stata Kernel.
8. The kernel launches and Stata launches automatically.
9. There is a 10 second hang (per the log file) and Stata crashes and the kernel restarts, restarting Stata in a loop. No input into the notebook from me, this happened automatically.
10. Kill kernel and quit notebook.

Thanks again for your help - this is no rush so whenever you have some time, I just thought I would let you know. Code for the kernel crash this time follows (I started a little earlier from the opening of Jupyter Notebook to close). Thanks! Greg


Is this an older version of Stata? I thought that Stata ic was phased out? 

I have a hunch of the error... There should be something like `stata-ic` in the same folder as `StataIC`. If you change the path to `stata-ic` instead it should work. I.e. 

```
/Applications/Stata/StataIC.app/Contents/MacOS/stata-ic
```

It's Stata 15 - I bought a license back in July. I usually just use R but am working on some projects with an advisor that is more accustomed to Stata packages.

It looks like the StataIC is in the only file which might be the issue...

![screen shot 2018-09-19 at 7 46 21 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40870603/45791040-14a62c00-bc45-11e8-921c-6499234343ab.png)
Oops attached wrong screenshot.
Also - no worries. If StataIC is the issue there probably aren't many more people than me who are going to experience it. It works fine in Windows so I can just run it there.

I was just curious and tried switching from console to automation in the next line of the config file and now it works!

Whatever the issue was that seemed to get around it.

This is fantastic. Thank you so much for putting it together!

Greg

While that first screenshot does mention StataIC, usually the executables are just named `Stata`, and not `StataIC`.
 
That's really interesting that there's only one file. Usually there are two:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/45793738-84c2ab00-bc61-11e8-9080-1f39d8d66b05.png)

`StataSE` is the executable that opens the GUI version of Stata, whereas `stata-se` is what opens the console version of Stata:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/45793796-ba679400-bc61-11e8-9376-90113ef5f272.png)

`stata_kernel` has two ways it can communicate with Stata. Either "automation", which communicates with the GUI version, or "console", which controls the console directly. By default, it uses "console" on Mac, because that allows it to have multiple independent sessions of Stata at a time. But switching it to "automation" will control the GUI. Since for some reason you only have a GUI and not the console, you'll need to use "automation".

I'm curious if all StataIC versions only come with the GUI method and not the console version...

Interesting. It does not seem to impact all StataIC versions as when I run it in Windows it runs without a GUI interface, so there must be some "console" only version that is operating under the hood there.

For curiosity purposes I may need to boot up a Linux VM build just because I'm curious how it is treated there, as I it should be similar to the Mac build.

Yes, on Windows you can only use automation. Stata console doesn't exist for Windows. 

See the description for `execution_mode` in the documentation: https://kylebarron.github.io/stata_kernel/getting_started/#general-settings

Understood. Well I will probably not be a ton of help diagnosing why the StataIC build for MacOS doesn't appear to have a "console" version, as this is outside the realm of my expertise.

For my purposes running via the GUI version is good enough (though obviously not as clean), so this workaround works for me.

I really appreciate all of your help. If there is anything you would like me to run to try and investigate further I would be more than happy to do what I can.

Thanks again for taking time out to help diagnose, I truly do appreciate it!

Greg

> though obviously not as clean

What isn't as clean?

Sorry - I just meant aesthetically/work flow wise. Running in Windows without a Stata instance running feels nicer because there isn't a program instance running in the foreground, as would be the case if there was an operational console version for IC. Obviously this doesn't matter in any practical way. My apologies for the confusion.
Also, by the way, what you created is fantastic and I really can't thank you enough.

> Running in Windows without a Stata instance running 

It actually is running! That's why the graph window still shows up if you try to make a graph. The differences is that on Windows, I can completely hide the Stata window from view, while on Mac I can only minimize it.

Understood. This has definitely improved (some of) my understanding of how your kernel works.

I was curious and installed a Linux build of StataIC, and it does install separate console and GUI versions, for whatever that is worth.

Thanks again! Greg

@gtotten 	In case you were wondering why StataCorp doesn't supply a Stata IC console version for Mac (tl;dr pay more)

From Stata support:

> Unix operating systems often have an optional graphical user interface so we
> need to include console versions of Stata for all flavors of Stata on those
> systems. 
> 
> The Mac operating system always has a graphical user interface so the console
> version of Stata on the Mac is a special tool that is included for power users.
> The Stata/IC for Mac is designed for regular Stata users and does not include a
> console version.
> 
> Originally the Mac versions of Stata were just like the Windows versions and
> did not have any console support.

Hello 

I am also having this issue where kernel runs Stata but would keep restarting. I am following the instruction and I understand that changing the configuration from console to automation is the key but I am not really sure how to do this. would appreciate some advice on where do I edit in the configuration file.

Open the file at `home directory/.stata_kernel.conf` and then change
```
execution_mode = console
```
to
```
execution_mode = automation
```

Sorry for the delay getting back to you. Thanks for getting this info for them - unsurprising that they take this approach, though it does seem silly given how rare these marginal use cases this likely impacts are and how little extra work I am assuming it would take to include it in the package. So it goes.

Thanks!

Greg

> @gtotten In case you were wondering why StataCorp doesn't supply a Stata IC console version for Mac (tl;dr pay more)
> 
> From Stata support:
> 
> > Unix operating systems often have an optional graphical user interface so we
> > need to include console versions of Stata for all flavors of Stata on those
> > systems.
> > The Mac operating system always has a graphical user interface so the console
> > version of Stata on the Mac is a special tool that is included for power users.
> > The Stata/IC for Mac is designed for regular Stata users and does not include a
> > console version.
> > Originally the Mac versions of Stata were just like the Windows versions and
> > did not have any console support.
Well you're welcome to register your displeasure with StataCorp

> Open the file at `home directory/.stata_kernel.conf` and then change
> 
> ```
> execution_mode = console
> ```
> to
> 
> ```
> execution_mode = automation
> ```
